snippet.textDisplay:
I don't see how building a computer is that difficult when you have the correct case and parts.


Basically, Razor are just releasing a compact computer case with laptop internals. Not very impressive.


You could easily compete with them by offering competitively priced computer hardware bundles, along with a "one size fits all" case, clearly marked cables, and a detailed installation video. Then you would get far better performance than you would with their case.
snippet.textOriginal:
I don't see how building a computer is that difficult when you have the correct case and parts.


Basically, Razor are just releasing a compact computer case with laptop internals. Not very impressive.


You could easily compete with them by offering competitively priced computer hardware bundles, along with a "one size fits all" case, clearly marked cables, and a detailed installation video. Then you would get far better performance than you would with their case.

snippet.textDisplay:
Concept fail:
- "Intel compute card does not come with ram or storage by default"
- RAM and Storage are inside the compute card, so they are even less upgradeable for noobs

- People who can't build a PC don't know which upgrade cards to buy to upgrade their old stuff
- It's literally just a NUC with a (male) PCIe connector

Such innovation, very magic quadrant.
snippet.textOriginal:
Concept fail: 
- "Intel compute card does not come with ram or storage by default"
- RAM and Storage are inside the compute card, so they are even less upgradeable for noobs

- People who can't build a PC don't know which upgrade cards to buy to upgrade their old stuff
- It's literally just a NUC with a (male) PCIe connector

Such innovation, very magic quadrant.

snippet.textDisplay:
Well, this better cost around $400-500 for Box and Intel Card thingy. Because the performance, even that of a 9900H, can be had in a Ryzen 3600 for $200. Add a case and PSU, each around $50, and a board and RAM, together maybe $140. Makes $390 in total with the benefit of being independent from whatever Intel offers next as an upgrade card.
And I think a basic, modern system isn't hard to build. There are just 7 parts (case, psu, board, cpu, ram, ssd, gpu), each of them can only go in one place in one orientation with cables that can only plug into the right socket. And we have stuff like online build configurators that tell you which parts work together. Lastly, that option offers unlimited upgradability (like 3.5" HDDs, extra PCI cards, even optical disk drives).
I don't think many people will buy this thing. It's only appeal is the cool look of that clean setup.
snippet.textOriginal:
Well, this better cost around $400-500 for Box and Intel Card thingy. Because the performance, even that of a 9900H, can be had in a Ryzen 3600 for $200. Add a case and PSU, each around $50, and a board and RAM, together maybe $140. Makes $390 in total with the benefit of being independent from whatever Intel offers next as an upgrade card.
And I think a basic, modern system isn't hard to build. There are just 7 parts (case, psu, board, cpu, ram, ssd, gpu), each of them can only go in one place in one orientation with cables that can only plug into the right socket. And we have stuff like online build configurators that tell you which parts work together. Lastly, that option offers unlimited upgradability (like 3.5" HDDs, extra PCI cards, even optical disk drives).
I don't think many people will buy this thing. It's only appeal is the cool look of that clean setup.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'd rather have a standardised computer with standardised parts than some Intel throw-it-all-together doo-hickey in a Razer case at this point. Plus, YouTube is absolutely FLOODED with tutorials on how to build a PC from the likes of our friendly neighbourhood tech channel: LTT but also guys like Carey Holzman who have been in the industry for YEARS. Keep people who don't like the idea of messing with computers to the OEMs with their non-standard bullshit and keep people with the know-how with their standard "do what you want" magic boxes. We don't need more non-standardness in the industry. It's not healthy and it's not fun for us.


Yeah you could say the graphics card upgrade options are good. The card design for the Intel NUC thing is OK but if your cooler dies, they're not going to sell an easy to replace part, same goes for the daughter board with the PCi express slots on it. If that dies; BOOM you're out of pocket majorly.
snippet.textOriginal:
I'd rather have a standardised computer with standardised parts than some Intel throw-it-all-together doo-hickey in a Razer case at this point. Keep people who don't like the idea of messing with computers to the OEMs with their non-standard bullshit and keep people with the know-how with their standard "do what you want" magic boxes. We don't need more non-standardness in the industry. It's not healthy and it's not fun for us. 


Yeah you could say the graphics card upgrade options are good. The card design for the Intel NUC thing is OK but if your cooler dies, they're not going to sell an easy to replace part, same goes for the daughter board with the PCi express slots on it. If that dies; BOOM you're out of pocket majorly.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is NOT more accessible. That NUC and all of its relatives cost as much or more than a low end (but higher performance) desktop machine that will end up roughly the same size. Longevity is also going to be an issue.

This seems to actually be a pitch for modulatory in server architecture, sold as an off the shelf development kit.

snippet.textDisplay:
So it's "fully modular", but the only thing that's easily swappable is the GPU? Nice aesthetic, but that's not groundbreaking; I can swap the GPU in my current case without tools either, the side panel just swings out of the way.


If the daughterboard contains the CPU, RAM and local storage then none of those components seem easily replaceable, only the unit as a whole would be. So, why does this exist?
snippet.textOriginal:
So it's "fully modular", but the only thing that's easily swappable is the GPU? Nice aesthetic, but that's not groundbreaking; I can swap the GPU in my current case without tools either, the side panel just swings out of the way. 


If the daughterboard contains the CPU, RAM and local storage then none of those components seem easily replaceable, only the unit as a whole would be. So, why does this exist?

snippet.textDisplay:
I used to relish opening up a stupidly massive PC and dumping out old parts and putting new stuff in.

Now I'm less of the enthusiast (life changes you) and just want the thing to work from the day it's slapped together, the case closed and work till the day it dies with minimal tinkering in between.

Now I prefer common sense mini-ITX systems with good airflow, a good lifespan and moderate-good gaming options.
snippet.textOriginal:
I used to relish opening up a stupidly massive PC and dumping out old parts and putting new stuff in.

Now I'm less of the enthusiast (life changes you) and just want the thing to work from the day it's slapped together, the case closed and work till the day it dies with minimal tinkering in between.

Now I prefer common sense mini-ITX systems with good airflow, a good lifespan and moderate-good gaming options.

snippet.textDisplay: This is such a stupid product. People out there really acting like "using a screwdriver" is justified getting a PC that will be slower, run hotter, be more expensive, and most importantly probably die out quickly. Jeez. Following a 30 minute "how to build a PC" guide isn't hard, and most of the modifications that this razer thingy allowes can be done in 10 seconds or less already.
